original_data.question: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent chest pain and palpitations. She also complains of dyspnea on exertion and has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months despite normal appetite. She has no history of serious medical illness. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and a grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur heard best over the apex. Diffuse wheezing and bilateral rales are present in the lung bases. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40% and a mass in the left atrium. A biopsy of the mass is likely to show which of the following?

options.A: Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells
options.B: Mixture of cells from different germinal layers
options.C: Encapsulated cluster of mature fat cells

model_response:
The presence of a left-atrial mass in this patient with intermittent chest pain and palpitations who also has dyspnea on exertion and weight loss is consistent with a diagnosis of atrial myxoma. This is the most common primary cardiac neoplasm, and it is most often found in the left atrium. The tumor is generally attached by a pedicle to the atrial wall, and it can lead to obstruction of the mitral valve orifice. Histologically, the tumor is composed of stellate or globular myxoma (lepidic cell) cells set in a background of myxoid stroma. The lesion is often surrounded by fibrous tissue, sometimes with giant cells and xanthomatous changes.

The other choices are not likely to be found in a myxoma. An encapsulated cluster of mature fat cells would be a lipoma. Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells would be a leiomyoma. An encapsulated cluster of malignant melanocytes would be a malignant melanoma. A mixture of cells from different germinal layers would be a teratoma.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Periodically stopping and starting.
An unpleasant sensation of irregular and/or forceful beating of the heart.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Difficult or labored breathing.
Physical or mental energy; hard work.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Record and study of past events.
Provision of diagnostic and/or therapeutic treatment.
A physical examination focusing on areas of interest other than the heart.

Any disturbances of the normal rhythmic beating of the heart or MYOCARDIAL CONTRACTION. Cardiac arrhythmias can be classified by the abnormalities in HEART RATE, disorders of electrical impulse generation, or impulse conduction.
A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
Post-systolic relaxation of the HEART, especially the HEART VENTRICLES.
DNA-(apurinic or apyrimidinic site) lyase (318 aa, ~36 kDa) is encoded by the human APEX1 gene. This protein plays a role in both DNA repair and the regulation of transcription.

A symptom and a finding during physical examination, characterized by a high-pitched, whistling sound during breathing. It results from the narrowing or obstruction of the respiratory airways. The most common causes of wheezing are asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tracheobronchitis, and pulmonary edema.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
The bottom concave portion of the lung that is situated on the convexity of the diaphragm.
A non-invasive cardiac ultrasound performed by placing the transducer on the chest.
The lower right and left chambers of the heart. The right ventricle pumps venous BLOOD into the LUNGS and the left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the systemic arterial circulation.
amount of blood pumped out of the left lower chamber of the heart with each heart beat
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
One of four chambers of the heart, which receives blood from the pulmonary veins and pumps blood through the mitral valve into the left ventricle.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
